Many schools want to do more to prevent substance use. But sometimes they aren’t sure how.
So the BDN looked for prevention programs considered among the best for reducing or delaying drug use, based on rigorous research. There are two main sources:

• The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration evaluated hundreds of behavioral health programs for quality of research and readiness for dissemination to create a registry of evidence-based practices.

• Meanwhile, the Center for the Study and Prevention of Violence at the University of Colorado Boulder created “Blueprints for Healthy Youth Development,” a registry of the programs that meet their rigorous standards.
Combining information from both resources produce seven well-studied drug prevention programs that also have clear and comparable information on how much they cost.

The cost per student in the first year was calculated by the Center for the Study and Prevention of Violence at the University of Colorado Boulder. The quality of research is according to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration.

Want more options for programs? Search through these 115 programs by choosing features you’re looking for. All programs are legacy programs on the National Registry of Evidence-based Programs and Practices.
Click on the bubble, then click “For more information” to get to the listing on the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration website.
There’s more information about what each feature means, and why it matters, below.

• Location: If you select “rural,” you’ll see programs that have been tested in a rural area. Certain programs are designed for certain locations, and it makes a difference because what might be helpful for a city kid might not be for a kid growing up on a farm. Research shows that rural kids and urban kids have different beliefs and habits about drug use.
• Setting: If you select “school,” you’ll see programs designed to take place at school. Many programs can be implemented at either a school or in some other setting.

• Family Involvement: If you select “yes,” you’ll see programs that require a family member to take part. Programs that involve a family member are usually more effective than ones that don’t, but sometimes families aren’t around.
• Age group: If you select “elementary school,” you’ll see programs that are designed for kids in that age range. Many programs have versions that can be implemented at different ages.

• Prevention category: “Universal” means that all kids would receive this program whether or not they are at an increased risk for substance use. “Selective” means that only certain at-risk kids receive the program — maybe kids whose parents use substances, or those who live in a high-crime neighborhood. “Indicated” means that the kids receiving the program might be showing early signs of substance abuse, or they’re struggling in another way, such as by not going to school or experiencing depression.
Programs with an orange bubble meet the requirements of The Center for the Study and Prevention of Violence at the University of Colorado Boulder for effectiveness.

Whether you’re a parent, guardian or someone who cares about children, it can be tricky to figure out what to do to prevent the young person in your life from getting into drugs, or what do if they’re already abusing drugs.
Here’s what to do if you think a kid has a problem with drugs:
• Talk with them. Ask questions. Don’t panic. Whether it’s drugs or not, they probably need someone to listen to them.

• Call a treatment hotline: 1-855-378-4373. This number, which is specifically for parents and guardians, is a toll-free helpline from the Partnership for Drug Free Kids. It’s open during usual working hours, but someone will call back if needed in the evening or on the weekend.

• Seek help, such as from an addiction specialist or mental health expert. A family doctor can point you in the right direction, or you can search for an addiction specialist near you with the map below.
Here’s what might put a kid at risk:

Some kids end up getting involved in drugs for no good reason at all. But research shows that events that make a childhood hard — such as emotional or sexual abuse, having a relative in jail or experiencing neglect — make it more likely for that kid to later become addicted to a substance.

Take a quiz by clicking here to find out how many adverse childhood experiences you had, or encourage a child in your life to take it. There are a host of other risk factors, too, such as a genetic predisposition or mental illness. You can read more about risk factors on youth.gov.
Here’s what guardians can do before a problem ever starts:

Make sure the kids in your life are able to do the things they love. Help them find a sport they like, a genre of books, a nice place to go for a walk. Then, despite all odds, guardians can try to make time for them do that thing.
Help them form strong friendships and relationships. Is there a teacher they get along with? Do they need help learning how to make friends? Can they spend an afternoon a week with their grandfather?
Teach them ways to cope with stress and feelings of darkness. Seek help from a mental health specialist if you think they’re struggling with anxiety or depression.
You can read about what protects kids from drug abuse on youth.gov, too.
Here’s what to look out for:
Mood changes, problems at school, new friends, forgetfulness and physical changes could all be signs that a teenager is abusing drugs. Read more about warning signs at drugfree.org.
